bibl.author: W.J. Hensley
bibl.title: W.J. Hensley to Walt Whitman, 6 March 1888
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p: Inspired by a perusal of some of your leaves of grass, especially "Starting from Paumanok", "Song of the Open Road" & "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, I dashed off the enclosed Sonnet, which I take the liberty of send to you, the rather to gratify my own pride, than to expect that you will esteem such a faulty production to be an honour.
However I think it better to leave it as it is

lg.l: Whitman, thy earnest cries have reached our shore,
Thou prophet of the old, & new En-Masse:
From world to world the glorious tidings pass,
Of which down-trodden mortals scarce before
Did dream, or if they did, with fire and gore
Raised Hell on Earth by setting class 'gainst class;
Thus crushing Freedom at her birth, alas!
And ripping up the mother that her bore.
But thou dost teach a common Brotherhood,
The Present joins the Past, the East the West,
And from their union spring a perfect brood,
Bound by the sacred ties of Comradeship,
To purify our Earth from Error's pest
Till her last Sun in waves eternal dip.

body.p: I hope you will not consider me to be taking a liberty, but merely to be paying a somewhat antiquated tribute (spontaneously) to the honor of a great genius.

postscript.p: "I dream'd a dream I saw a city invincible to the attacks of the whole of the rest of the earth, I dreamed that was the new city of friends."
